div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 02, 1905. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

Wednesday, August 2, 1905.
SALES OF SUDAN LANDS.

Though a certain amount of annoyance may be caused by the recent decree of the Sudan Government forbidding sales of land by natives without the consent of the pro- vincial governors, we are convinced that the measure is, in the main, both wise and just. The Egyptian and British Governments have not occupied the Sudan solely with a view to their own profit, nor do they intend to permit strangers to buy up valuable lands for a song and oust native proprietors from their holdings by taking advantage of their embarrassments We are prepared to hear severe criticisms passed by interested in- dividuals on the action of the Sudan author ities. They will be accused of restricting trade, restraining free commercial intercourse, inter- fering with free contracts, and so forth ad nauseam, but their detractors will find it hard to explain why a Government, which exists ostensibly for the benefit of the Sudanese, should not interfere in contracts in which one of the parties is as a rule an astute and esurient foreigner, the other dusky gentleman without sufficient foresight to look beyond the day after to-morrow, and without the knowledge that might otherwise enable him to obtain a fair price for his hands. In our opinion tie Sudan Government has only done its duty in checking or regulating sales which might have unpleasant results in the future. The Sudanese who parts with his lands for a trifle to-day, and is content with the trifle, will be the first to complain when he realises to-morrow that be has made a bad bargain, and being of a hot-tempered and somewhat fanatical nature, may attempt to settle accounts vi et arms. That a number of European landlords, com- pelled by the climate to be absentees for half the year, should become owners of the greater part of the tillable areas of the Sudan, is not the intention of the Government, whose in- terests will not be served by agrarian quarrels between natives and Europeans or by the speculative purchase of lands by individuals who cannot develop them. We have no doubt that certain large areas which require irriga- tion or reclamation on a scale that is far beyond the means of the small proprietor will fall into European hands, and see no reason why they should not. There are likely to be several Kom Ombos in Senaar and the Ghazireh Province, concessions that can only be deve- loped by the expenditure of large sums that are likely enough to run into six or even seven figures, but we do not imagine that the Sudan Government intends to allow every petty trader who has entered the country to offer derisory sums to natives for lands that he hopes to sell at fifteen or twenty times their cost price. The days are past when Govern- mets permitted the hardy pioneer to acquire gold miner or fat acres of arable land with the expenditure of a few hawks bells and beads, with a little rum and calico thrown in.

div.head: MANCHURIA.
div.p: RUSSIANS NOT SURROUNDED.
DESPATCH FROM LINIEVITCH.
St. Petersburg, August 1.

General Linievitch has telegraphed to the Tsar contradicting the newspaper reports that the Russian army is surrounded, and declaring that all Japanese attempts to approach him have been unsuccessful. (Reuter)

div.head: VLADIVOSTOK
div.p: INHABITANTS EMIGRATING EN MASSE.
St. Petersburg, August 1.
The inhabitants of Vladivostok are emigrat- ing en masse to Blagonestchensk. {Reuter.)

div.head: UNREST IN RUSSIA.
div.p: SHOPS AND RESTAURANTS SACKED.
St. Petersburg, August 1.
Owing to a strike at Rostoff the Don trade is at a standstill. In conflicts with the police two strikers have been killed.
Two thousand hungry reservists sacked the grocers’ shops and restaurants at Goru and Kalwarja, near Warsaw, and a policeman has been shot dead at Warsaw. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN NATIONAL ASSEMBLY.
div.p: MEETING OF COUNCIL
St. Petersburg, August 1.

The Tsar presides at a meeting of the coucil to-day, for the final consideration of the scheme for a National Assembly. It is un- likely that there will be any modifications. It is proposed that the elections shall take place on the 1st of October, and that the Assembly hall meet on the 1st of November. The sitting will be private, but the president may admit the members of the press. (Reuter).

div.head: GERMANY AND THE BALTIC SEA.
div.p: REASSURING STATEMENT.
Berlin, August 1.

The Foreign Office deprecates the outcry raised by the German Press regarding the visit of the Charnel Squadron to the Baltic Sea. It has no anxiety at all on the matter. Germany is prepared to give the fleet the usual hos- pitality, coal, provisions, and supplies. (R.)

div.head: KAISER AT COPENHAGEN.
div.p: Copenhagen, August 1.
The Emperor William is staying at the Royal Castle. (Reuter.)

div.head: THREATENED COTTON STRIKE.
div.p: OPERATIVES DEMAND INCREASED WAGES:
London, August 1.

The ballot of the cotton operatives resulted almost unanimously in favor of a strike on the l9th inst. unless wages be raised 5 per centum. The Committee of the International Federation of Cotton Spinners and Manu- facturers has decided to urge spinners in Europe and America to buy no American cotton during the next three months, with a view to preventing next season opening with the present high prices. Delegates from the prin- cipal countries of Europe were present. (R.)

div.head: OVERFLOWING OF RED RIVER.
div.p: Ha Noi, August 1.
The Red River has burst the right dyke. The provinces of Kadong and Hanan are inundated and the crops are affected. (Havas)

div.head: YELLOW FEVER AT NEW ORLEANS
div.p: New Orleans, August 1.
There were twenty-one cases of yellow fever here yesterday, five of which were fatal. (R.)

div.head: RACING.
div.p: London, August 1.

Goodwood Steward Cup. 1. Xeny; 2. Thrush; 3. Polymelus. 17 ran. Betting: 2 to 5 (?) against Xeny ; 100 to 15 against Thrush ; 9 to 2 against Polymelus. Won by a length and a half.,One head between second and third. (R.)

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: London, August 1.
Surrey beat Middlesex by ten wickets. (R.)

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: The Brindisi Mail will be distributed at the G.P.O., Alexandria, at 9.30 p.m. to-day.
Stray and Ownerless DOGS found in the Rod el Farag district of Cairo during to- morrow night and at daylight on Friday will be poisoned by the police.
Lots Turcs — We are informed by the Credit Lyonnais that the winning number in the drawing for the “gros lot” of the Ottoman Railway Lottery yesterday was 1,278,818.
Leon Fehmy’s Case —Leon Fehmy, accused of assault and attempted blackmail at the expense of Orphi Pasha, will come before the Cairo Assize Court on the 12th inst.
The Plague.—Yesterday’s buletin records two fresh cases (one fatal) at Alexandria, both the victims being natives. Two deaths also took place in hospital. One recovery is re- ported from Kafr Zayat.

Alhambra Theatre. — The Guardia Italian dramatic company, is expected to arrive at Alexandria on Friday from Europe and will open at the Alhambra the following evening with Sardou’s 4-act comedy Fedora.

Suez Canal.—20 vessels passed through the Canal on the 29th and 30th inst., of which 12 were British, 4 German, 2 French, 1 Span- ish, 1 Turkish. The receipts for the two days were frs. 561,887.52, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 8,856,722.15.

Big Fire at Assiout. — Our Assiout Correspondent writes:—On Sunday night a big fire broke out in the house of Khashaba Bey, one of the wealthiest men in Assiout. The outbreak was due to the fact that a small boy, six years old, had set fire to a curtain and left it burning as if nothing had happened. Nobody noticed anything until the whole house was ablaze. The Inspector of the Interior happened to be at Assiout and worked hard in trying to subdue the flames, together with the wekil of the moudirieh and the hukumdar; but the conflagration continued for about fourteen hours. They, however, succeeded in confining it to the house where it broke out. The damage is estimated at £16,000.

Where to go in the Summer Evenings.— We need not remind our readers that one of the greatest sights of Egypt is that of the Pyramids, especially by moonlight. A great want has been filled by the establishment of a bar and restaurant there,and visitors all testify to the excellent arrangements that have been made for catering to their wants at this rather out-of-the-way spot. The “Pyramids Bar and Restaurant,” situated opposite Mena House Hotel and at the foot of the Pyramids, is a place where one can obtain everything one requires to satisfy the “inner man” at very reasonable rates. A sure guarantee that all the mineral waters, wines, spirits, beers, etc., retailed at this bar and restaurant are of the best quality, is the fact that they are supplied by Mr. N. Spathis, the well-known merchant and mineral water manufacturer. [Advt.]

The Gardner-Brown Troupe. —The Gard- ner-Brown variety company is at present per- forming nightly at the Alcazar Music-hall in Cairo, where it has met with such success that Mr. Gardner-Brown has decided that his company shall remain in Cairo until the middle of September, when they will continue on their way to India. The Sisters Romaine, of whom Cairo music-hall goers retain pleasant recollec- tions from their performances here last year, form the chief attraction of the troupe. These two young comediennes sing duets of lighter vein with great “verve” and also dance grace- fully, and the audience is always reluctant to let them leave the stage. Mr. Leo Montague is an excellent comedian, sings well, dances well, and does not indulge in vulgarity which is so much in evidence on the music-hall stage. Mr. Geo. Montague is most amusing and clever in his ventriloquial efforts and is always greet- -ed with much applause. Mr. Gardner-Brown himself provides an excellent Bioscope “show,” and Mrs. Gardner-Brown sings a number of well-known songs, which are illustrated by lantern-slides, in a very pleasing manner. It is necessary to point Out to the management of this music-hall that a very great improvement in the playing of the band is to be desired. Not content with playing out of tune to such a degree as to jar upon the nerves of every mu- sical and unmusical person in the hall, the members of this band,consisting of more than a dozen, absolutely disregard each other’s efforts and so fail entirely in combination. In addi- tion to these two unpardonable sins, of neither of which any band, pretentious of a Knowledge of music should be guilty, they greatly depre- ciate the efforts of the artistes by playing so loudly that one has to strain one’s ears in order to hear the sounds proceeding from the stage. It would be well for the band-conductor to bear in mind that the audience is desirous of hear- ing the performers and can have but little interest in a band of such poor quality.

div.head: THE RIFAA CASE.
div.p: JUDGMENT AGAIN UPHELD.

The Court of Cassation, consisting of Ahmed Bey Afifi, president, Yehia Bey Ibrahim, Youssef Bey Chawky, Ahmed Bey Chawky, 1 Ahmed Bey Helmi, and Mr. Halton, sat yesterday morning to hear the appeal lodged by Hassan Bey Wassif, Moudir of Ghirgeh, against the sentence passed by the Criminal Court of Appeal on June 29, by which Hassan Bey Wassif, the Cadi, and the clerk of Badawi Bey Rifaa were condemned to two years’ imprisonment and the two witnesses to the alleged forgery were each sentenced to six months’ imprisonment.

The office of counsel for the prosecution was filled by Ali Bey Abou El Fatouh, while the defendants were represented in Court by their advocates, among them Omar Bey Loutfi, Skander Bey Ammoun, and other well-known members of the Cairo Bar.

After the Court had refused the coun- sel for the prosecution’s demand to produce a letter of Hassan Bey Wassif in Court, the case for the prosecution was heard. At 10.30 a.m. the Court retired for a quarter of an hour, and on the resumption of the sitting Omar Bey Loufti pleaded the cause of the ex-moudir. The principal heads of his defence were:-

(1.) The copies of conclusions of counsel for complainant and the voluminous written pleadings of the Parquet had not been served on counsel for the defendant till one day previous to the hearing, and the Court had refused to allow an adjournment to enable the defence to prepare a reply.
(2.) The Court had not given counsel for the defence sufficient time to finish his pleading before it rose.

(3.) After the judgment of the Assiout Court Badawi Bey Rifaa had admitted before wit- nesses that he had signed the power of attorney with full knowledge of the facts and had denied the fact, by alleging that he had been imposed upon, at the instigation of a relative in whose house he had been staying.

(4.) After judgment of First Instance had been delivered the Parquet filed in the dossier of the case a letter calculated to influence the judges in their opinion of one of the items of evidence for the prosecution, and that this letter was filed without giving notice thereof, to the defendants or their counsel.

After hearing Omar Bey Loufti’s defence and that of counsel for the remainder of the accused, the Court retired to consider its verdict and 1.35 p.m. returned and gave its decision rejecting the appeal.

div.head: THE HAMADE INCIDENT.
div.p: A RIDICULOUS STORY.

A very extraordinary version of the Hamade incident has found its way into certain French and German contemporaries, who state that Sheikh Hamade was arrested under the belief that he bore a proclamation from the late Grand Mufti of Egypt announcing that the Turks were no longer worthy to hold the Caliphate and, so to speak, excommunicating the Sultan. We need not say that there is not a word of truth in this ridiculous story, which has probably been sent on its travels by an opponent of the late Sheikh Mohamed Abdou, whose whole life makes his participation in an Arab conspiracy abso- lutely unthinkable.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL AGRICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: At the last meeting of the Higher Commis- sion of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, held under the presidency of H.H. Prince Hussein Pasha Kamel, a vote of thanks to the Government (with whom was coupled the name of Mr. Machell, Adviser to the Ministry of the Interior) was passed, for the activity and effectiveness with which the fight against the cotton worm has been carried on.
A similar vote of thanks to the Ministry of Public Works was passed, for the way in which they have arranged for the irrigation of the lands in spite of the low state of the Nile.

div.head: BEWARE OF PRAWNS.
div.p: Dr. Meshaka of Cairo writes:- Allow me to bring to your notice the following. I had occa- sion to have under my care a few cases apparently similar to the suspicious choleraic cases reported in Luxor a few weeks ago. They resemble cholera in having a severe onset, severe colic, and the other usual symptoms, with great dejection; but here the similarity ends. In about three or four hours or more the symptoms abate and the case takes a favora- ble turn, while on the following day the patient very possibly goes to work, only a little depressed and weak. The lighter cases are much more numerous, and need no special reference, except that most take the same Course as the first. In all the worst cases, and in most of the light ones, I have found that eating prawns lies at the root of the evil. Vendors care little whether their prawns are fresh and good, or old and putrid, as long as they sell; and since nobody else cares either, the poor folk are allowed to be poisoned.

div.head: LOCUSTS IN THE RED SEA
div.p: THE FAYOUM’S EXPERIENCES
(From Our Correspondent.)
Suez, Tuesday.

The Khedivial Mail liner Fayoum, which arrived at Suez yesterday, reports that while in the Massawoh channel, for a distance of three miles, she steamed through millions of drown- ed locusts, and that several thousands of them dropped on the ship's decks.

div.head: CREW OF PRINCESSE MARIE AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From Our Correspondent).
Suez, Tuesday.

The S.S. Siam, which arrived at Suez this morning from the Far East, had on board the captain and crew of the S.S. Princesse Marie, belonging to the East Asiatic Company, which was sunk by the Russian auxiliary cruiser Terek on the 22nd June while in the China Sea on a voyage from Europe to Singapore, Hongkong, Shanghai, and Yokohama. This vessel, according to the captain’s statement, had no contraband of war whatever on board.

div.head: KHEDIVE’S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: This morning the usual reception in honor of the birthday ot H.H. the Khedive took place at Rae el Tin Palace. The acting Regent, Hussein Pasha Fakhry, presided over the function, which was well attended both by Europeans and natives. The arrangements made by the police outside the Palace were very satisfactory and everything passed off most successfully. Among those present were the Ministers, the diplomatic agents of the Powers, the Under-Secretaries, and a number of native and European notables.

The Ministries, with the Gouvernorat and other public offices, were closed, and the con- sulates flew their flags in honor of the day, while Cherif Pasha-street and most of the principal streets were brightly decoreted with bunting.
A telegram has been dispatched by the acting Regent to H.H. the Khedive congratul- ating him on his thirty-second birthday.

Similar messages have been sent by many high officials and notables, and the Egyptian Press voices the public sentiment in wishing his Highness a long and prosperous reign, a wish with which we associate both ourselves and our readers.
Readings of the Koran and a “zikr” will be held in honor of the occasion this evening at Ras el Tin Palace.

div.head: COTTON WORM.
div.p: The official weekly report on the work done for the destruction of the cotton worm shows that the number of feddans attacked during the week ending July 29 is considerably less than the number attacked during the previous week, the difference in all being 21,112 feddans.

Reports from the provinces of Ghizeh, Fayoum, Minieh, and Beni Souef show that there has been no re-appearance of the worm during the week in those provinces. The re- ports from other provinces are as follows :—
Kalioubieh :—106 feddans, belonging to 50 proprietors, have been attacked and 113 feddans have been cleared by 1,071 children.
Menoufieh 60 feddans, belonging to 18 proprietors, have been attacked, and 75 fed- dans have been cleared by 460 children.
Gharbieh:- 554 feddans, belonging to 185 proprietors, have been attacked and 471 of these have been cleared by 1,019 children.
Sharkieh:- 36 feddans, belonging to 42 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 142 children.
Behera :—16,937 feddans, belonging to 427 proprietors, have been attacked and 16,483 have been cleared by 37,104 children.
Dakahlieh :—1,118 feddans, belonging to 283 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 2,946 children.
Damietta:- 41 feddans, belonging to 22 proprietors, have been attacked and have all been cleared by 220 children.
The active measures which are being taken for the destruction of the Nedwet el Assal are giving satisfactory results.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. Trojan Prince, from Antwerp and London, left Malta on Tuesday and is due here on Friday next.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not bold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair plan to all, to permit — within certain neccessary limits — free discussion.
BATHING AT RAMLEH.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Dear Sir,—In regard to Ramleh bathing I confess to having read the complaint of “Mer- maid” with astonishment. She must be a prude. What can be more picturesque than the brown colour of the bodies of bathing natives? It is a fine sight to see them swim- ming, and I am always glad to see that they like their seabaths. They never molest bathing and swimming Europeans, and after all it is their own country and their own coast. I think "Mermaid” is quite mistaken in her views.— Yours very truly,
A Reader.

div.head: NOTES FROM CYPRUS.
div.p: OPENING OF RAILWAY.
(From our Correspondent).
Nicosia, July 27.
The temperature during the last week has been somewhat higher in the plains, ranging up to 102° and 103° Fahrenheit in the shade.

The formal opening of the Cyprus Govern- ment Railway will not take place until some time in the autumn, when the Government returns to Nicosia. The line will, however, be open to traffic from the 1st proximo between Nicosia and Famagusta. Steady pro- gress is being made with the construction of the line between Nicosia and Morphou, a distance of some 24 miles. It is greatly to be hoped that money will be forthcoming to make it possible to extend that portion of the line as far as Karavostassi, a distance of 12 miles beyond Morphou. Karavostassi is a small natural harbour in the south bend of Morphou Bey, and a considerable quantities of goods are regularly shipped from there to Alexandria and other places. It is the nearest and most convenient shipping place for the whole of that locality, embracing Morphou, Lefka, and the lovely Marathassa Valley. Karavostassi receives for shipment every year several million oranges and lemons from Lefka, and large consignments of fruit and vegetables from the other two places.
WELCOME INNOVATIONS.

There is some talk of the establishment of a creamery and ice-making factory near Nicosia. It is a much needed want. It is almost im- possible to obtain good fresh butter—certainly not through the summer—and cream and cheese made by modern methods, and with improved appliances, are also difficult to get. I have alluded before now to the lack of ice and refrigerating facilities, and if Nicosia wishes to be regarded as at all up-to-date she ought certainly to make a move in the direction here indicated .
CYPRUS AS A PLACE OF ARMS.

Your recent article on “Cyprus as a place of arms” has been read here with much inte- rest, and residents in Cyprus not unnatu- rally hope that the political changes now taking place may have the effect of drawing attention to the various advantages of the Island and help towards developing her un- doubted possibilities.
NEW WEEKLY PAPER.

A new weekly paper has lately been started, called the “Semaia tis Kyprou,” the proprietor of which is, I understand, Mr. Th. Theodo- tou. The editorship, it is stated, will be undertaken by Mr. Catalanos, late editor of the “Evagoras,” which was recently suppres- sed by the Government.
NEW HOTEL AT PLATRES.

A new hotel has lately been opened at Platres, the charming little village, situated at the southern slope of Mt. Troodos. The manager and proprietor is Mr. Theodotou of Limassol. This village is becoming very popular in the summer among the higher classes of Limassol, and quite a number of pretty villas have been built there during the last two or three years.
EGYPTIAN VISITORS.
Colonel Laffan, R.A.M.C., and Mrs. Laffan, and Dr. and Mrs. Harper, all of Cairo, are now staying on Mt. Troodos.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL,
div.p: His Excellency Mahmoud Pasha Sidky, Governor of Alexandria, who has been on a visit to London, took luncheon with the Lord Mayor and the Lady Mayoress at the Mansion House on the 25th ult. He was accompanied by Mr. Lionel Sandars, Judge of the Court of Appeal.
The Marquis Salvago-Raggi Diplomatic Agent and Consul General for Italy, leaves to- morrow for a period of three months, during which Count A. Gonzaga will act for him.
Count de Serionne will leave for Europe this week.
Mr. Dupuis sailed from Port Said yesterday for Europe.
Captain E. B. Powell, 2nd Battalion Rifle Brigade, leaves Cairo for Khartoum to-night in Order to join the headquarters of his batta- lion.
Mr. Horace O’Donnell of the Quarantine Board, is leaving for Europe on 3 1/2 months leave of absence.
Dr Owen Richards has been attached to the Kasr-el-Aini Hospital at a salary of L.E. 20 per month.
M. Mony Sabin will shortly leave Europe for the East. He is being despatched by the French Government to study and report upon the actual influence of France in the countries, Syria, and Egypt.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: RIFLE SHOOTING.
HONOR FOR LOCAL SHOTS.

We note with satisfaction that at the great annual rifle meeting of the National Rifle Association just concluded at Bisley, two of our local shots, Messrs. Craig and Schilizzi, representing the Cairo B.R. Club and the Alexandria B.R. Club respectively, had the honor of being presented to King Edward on the occasion of his Majesty's visit to present the prizes.

The shooting this year at the Bisley meeting, which annually attracts from almost all parts of the world, has been of a remarkably high order, and speaks volumes for the infan- try weapon of the British service, which has again proved itself to be equally as good, if not slightly superior to any other military rifle in existence.

We congratulate Mr. Craig, whose name appears in at least six of the prize lists, on his success; and we would express the hope that our local rifle clubs may be more numerously represented in the future at that great rendez- vous of riflemen.
Cricket
E.T.C. v. CORPL. NEW'S XI

E.T.C

div.head: GAMBLERS OF THE GUTTER.
CHILD BACKERS IN COPPER AND THE USURER OF THE STREET- CORNER.
div.p: BY AN EMPLOYER OF LABOUR.

It is a hopeful sign that a spirit of in- trospection is just now abroad among us. We are hearing a good deal, amongst other things, about the "degeneration of the national cha- racter,” and undoubtedly it is a subject de- serving of most earnest self-examination. It is my purpose to allude here to one unmistak- able feature of this degeneracy, which I have some opportunity of observing closely, and which no one can deny is acting as a potent drag upon the moral and material well being of the masses of our people, both young and old.

Engrafted upon an alarming amount of poverty and want, so largely deducible from an obsolete fiscal policy, a spirit of reckless thriftlessness is apparent, which shows itself in no more pronounced form than in the reckless gambling which seems to be the end- all and be-all of the bulk of our poorer classes at the present time. In fact, the extent to which gambling on horse-racing has infected the national life of the masses will hardly be credited by those whose tastes or general condemnation of this particular vics has removed them from any intimacy with its statistics.

It is not among those who can better afford this species of excitement that the greatest harm is being worked, but among those poverty-stricken thousands whose daily bread depends upon the sweat of their brows, and who barely exist in a state of perennial want, in our great centres of population. Is it pos- sible to imagine any more miserable spectacle than that of wretched men, who cannot afford to keep their unhappy families from semi- starvation, but who nevertheless, by hook or by crook, scrape enough together to back a horse with the tempter at the street-corner, in the demoralising hope, which no failure will cause them to abandon, that some day luck will come their way? It is a hope which tends to depress all genuine effort in the workless loafer and in the small wage-earner alike.

Go any day into such a place as one of our great meat markets. There, if you know what to look for, you will find the gutter bookie in shoals, and doing his business under the very noses of the police. The regrettable thing is that so few, comparatively, are ever interfered with, and, in consequence, some very unfor- tunate inferences are drawn. But until penal- ties are very largely increased the evil will continue.

Worst of all, however, is the fact that the rising generation are quite as much, if not even more deeply, vitiated than their fathers by the fever of chance. There are bookmakers who devote themselves nowadays to betting with boys. They will take coppers, even down to single pennies, and so vast are the numbers of their young clients that they find it pays them excellently. To indemnify themselves for their offer of facilities in such small sums, they compel these boy gamblers to bet on the composite system, that is to say, they cannot win by backing a single horse in coppers, but must spot a placed horse in three races. It is, of course, a much harder task, and winners are correspondingly reduced in numbers, but the bait held out is a bigger prize for the successful backer.

These copper bookies swarm all round the warehouses and big printers’ estalblishment, in the neighbourhood of which every day purblind youngsters may be seen running up to them with their slips of paper and a few coppers. These boys are of all ages, from twelve upwards, earning from 5s. to 10s. a week. Numbers of them live in the East End, and tramp every day about three miles to their work in the City, and back again. Many of them have to pay over their earnings to their parents, with the exception of a shilling or eighteen-pence a week, and deliberately walk backwards and forwards between work and home so that they may thus save a few pence to back a horse with their bookie. And for the same purpose I have known them frequently to go without food in the middle of the day.

The consequence of all this in that they become careless and inattentive at work, until retribution overtakes them,and they lose their employment. Many employers, recognising the demoralising influence of some of thee halfpenny papers, with their racing tips and betting prices, have prohibited their introduction into their premises. But the boys somehow or other contrive to smuggle them in, and while they spend all their morning thinking- in place of attention to work—of what they shall back at lunch-time, during the afternoon their minds are employed in wondering whether their hor- ses will win, for the wily bookie of the gutter does not allow his copper clients to back their fancies both ways. At last, of course, as these wretched boys get thoroughly hypnotised, they not infrequently end in robbing their employ- ers or parents, and are tempted to adopt any means to supply themselves with money. But there is another means to hand by which this downward descent is facilitated.

Just as there is the gutter bookmaker, so there is his complement, the gutter usurer. This latter individual will lend any sum, down to sixpence, which he deems within the paying capacity of his clients, with whose circums- tances he is invariably well acquainted.
There is a man, whom I have frequently watched, in a certain London district, who is doing an immense business as a moneylender of small sums. His usual loans are sixpence or

a shilling. On the former he charges an interest of a halfpenny, on the latter a penny. It is generally towards the end of the week that his clients come to him, and his loans must always be paid on the following payday at the week’s end. He therefore makes an exceptionally quick turnover.

He has got about 6,000 to 7,000 names on his books, of which number the greater part are pretty regular customers requiring his accommodation each week, and thus, at the rate of 1s. 8d. in tee pound, he has become a wealthy man. His haunts are the doorways of certain public-houses, and the neighbourhood of warehouses and works at times when his knowledge of his customers’ hours of egress and probable necessities tells him that busi- ness is to be done. In order to get through the press of work that besets him, he is now always accompanied by an assistant, and when much racing is toward he is exceptionally busy.

It is a queer business, and a feature of the strange invisible life of our masses. If of less harmful character than that of the bookie; it undoubtedly fosters and is fostered by the same demoralisation upon which the latter battens. To the usurer resorts the boy who has wasted his little all in vain attempts upon the gutter bookmaker, but who cannot rest without the wherewithal to continue in the same course. Probably Sixpence is too much for him to borrow, so he combines with two equally broken companions, on the scale of twopence apiece.

The only security the usurer requires is the borrower’s place of business ; his home is nothing. If he fails to pay up, the usurer pays a visit to the borrower’s foreman, who is, not improbably, also a client of the former, and the wretched debtor, youth or man, also finds himself in the streets and out of work. Facilis descensus, for even the gutter has its grades of solvency.

As may be imagined, the power which such a man gradually absorbs in a district is as wonderful as his gains, and his influence upon the social life of his sphere of action often manifests itself in many singular forms. Not the least curious is the use to which he is sometimes put by the unhappy women whose partners in life he assists to his fellow- knight of the gutter. Finding themselves often left without the bare necessities of existence for themselves and their children, they visit the usurer and procure small sums, which are debited to their husbands, and thus, in- directly, they succeed in obtaining from their gambling helpmates something to rub along with which they would otherwise be left without.

In this respect the gutter usurer may seem to be something of a benefactor, but he is undoubtedly the means also of increasing the misery and acerbity of these wretched homes, where the husband's liability is too often avenged by blows and foul abuse.

Thus the eternal misery of our humblest masses is piled up year by year, under its high priests, the gutter bookie and usurer. The ill-gotten money which is occasionally won from the former rarely finds its way to any other bourne than the pot-house bar. The winner for a brief period becomes a gutter hero among his mates, and ruffles it as a ’ente fellow. jTo win, if possible, Beems more demoralising than to lose; for the working-man, who thus suddenly comes into a bit, receives along with it no notion of thrift. As I have too often had occasion to observe, he at once loses his head. He in- continently goes off work and loafs about from pothouse to pothonse until his gains are spent. Then, having sacrificed his regular wages, he once more turns up to work, and if, as is possibly the case, he finds himself cast out, he joins the great army of the un- employed, and sinks one stage lower in the social scale.

Such are certain of the influences which are working for the disintegration of the lower social levels of our national life, and it is very certain that if they cannot be shocked we must resign ourselves to an inevi- table, if gradual, process of national deca- dence.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

British Chamber of Commerce.- We would draw the attention of manufacturers and mer- chants to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, which was formed in 1896 with the sole onject of assisting British trade in this country. The services of the Chamber are always at the disposal of any member desiring information on trade matters generally, including the question of appointing suitable agents. AS no fee is charged for such advice, it is obviously in the interests of all British traders here to become members, especially when it is remembered that the annual sub- scription is merely the nominal one of 1 pound. The latter payment also includes a copy of the monthly journal issued by the Chamber. Home enquirers can obtain further particulars from our London office, 36, New Broad-street, which acts as agents to the Chamber.

div.head: MATTERS OF MOMENT.
Pith of the Press Comments. THE POLITICAL CRISIS.
div.p: “Times.”

Mr. Balfour’s statement of the decision of the Government not to regard the vote of last Thursday as a proper ground for dissolution or resignation took the form of a reasoned exa- mination of precedents and of constitutional doctrine. He observed that there seems to be in many quarters an idea that when a Govern- ment suffers a defeat of any kind its only constitutional course is to resign. That idea has, no doubt, been sedulously propagated by the Opposition, yet it is scarcely conceivable that it can be seriously entertained by any one possessing the smallest knowledge of the past. Mr. Balfour showed that few, if any, Govern- ments in this country that had existed for four or five years had escaped defeats which were not regarded as entailling their resignation. . . The Opposition, of course, maintain that the circum-tances in this case are such as to invest a defeat inflicted by a trick upon a vote in Supply with such overwhelming importance that it ought at once to be followed by resigna- tion. That is a very natural view to be held by an Opposition which displays, as Mr. Balfour observed, all that avidity for office which it imputes as a crime to the present Ministers. But it is not a conclusive argument. The Op- position had last night an opportunity to prove that the vote of Thursday means that the Ministers have lost the confidence of the House of Commons. They could have gone on with the vote of censure upon Sir Edward Grey’s motion. They elected to withdraw it. The essential point about a defeat is whether it does or does not show that the Government has lost the confidence of the majority. The Opposition have conclusively settled that point in favor of Mr. Balfour.
“ Telegraph.”

Who ran away last night? There was an opportunity for the House of Commons to have passed a real vote of censure upon the Government, which the Opposition has traduc- ed and slandered in language that has rarely, if ever, been employed in political controversy in this country. On the showing of their own leaders any division adverse to the Go- vernment is a vote of censure, and therefore to have voted against and to have defeated Sir Alexander Acland-Hood’s motion for the adjournment—explicity moved to give the Opposition an opportunity to divide—would have been followed by the immediate resigna- tion of this “unspeakable” and “perjured” Ministry. What did these loose-tongued politi- cians do? They ran away, because they knew they would be beaten hopelessly in the Lobby, And yet, because by a clever and not illegitim- ate stratagem they stole a march on the Go- vernment on Thursday, they say—though not one of them believes it—that Mr. Balfour has lost the confidence of the House of Commons. If their statement were true they could force a resignation, or a dissolution, or both, to- morrow. As we have observed, the statement is not true. It is the cant of the whole business that sickens one.
“Chronicle”

The Prime Minister based his defence or precedents. These prove nothing. There are precedents for all three courses which were open to him— for resignation and for dissolu- tion, as well as for “proceeding without refer once to the incident.” Each case must be judged on its merits, and precedents are of no value except in connection with all the circum- stances.
“Daily News.”

The expected has happened. Mr. Balfour being offered resignation or humiliation, has chosen the humiliation. The vote of Thursday is to be as though it had not been. The appeal at the Foreign Office is to be forgotten. Most Ministers are only prepared to sacrifice their ease and comfort for the public good. This one will go one better. He will sacrifice his, honor. Like the medieval mystic, he is prepared to abandon not only happiness, but even bis soul’s salvation so long as the world is saved.
“Manchester Guardian.”
In ancient Egypt it is recorded to have been a cause of great public concern that

whenever there was a house on fire the sacred cats would insist on running up and throw- ing themselves into the flames, in spite of the representations of the priests that this could serve no public object. No doubt the “unsought volunteers of death” greatly in- creased by this practice the sanctity attached to the surviving members of their caste, and no doubt there will be a lump in the “Daily Telegraph's” throat to-day as it speaks of Mr. Balfour’s moral loveliness. But the point is whether all these saintly men are not getting in the country’s way with their saintliness, whether the Premier, with all his charm and ingenuity, does not overrate the country’s need for sacred cats and under- rate its need for profane, Vulgar firemen.
“TEMPS.”

Mr. Balfour, it is said, has stated a thousand times that he would not resign while he had a majority. He still has a majority. His defeat was accidental; it was not decisive. Yet, it was not astonishing that he should be beaten. His Government is weak. It is weak because it is old. The end may not come now, but it is not very far off. Sometimes a change of domes- tic policy in England involves a change of external policy. In this case it almost certainly will not.

div.head: TSAR AND KAISER MEET.
div.p: “Times”

The sudden meeting of the Kaiser and the Tsar on board their yachts off a little island in the Baltic is certainly dramatic, and was doubtless intended to be dramatic by one of the chief actors. Nobody can suspect the Em- peror Nicholas of any desire for display, or of skill in devising coups de theatre which are intended to impress the European public. The Emperor William, on the other hand, has repeatedly shown that he has an irrepressible taste for exhibitions of the sort, and some ingenuity in devising them. . . . . . . That the Emperor Nicholas II. should gladly take an opportunity of pouring forth his woes into the bosom of a man of his own rank, who professes profound friendship for him and for his people, can cause but little surprise to those who remember the character of the Tsar.
“Standard,”

We cannot for one moment imagine that the purpose of the meeting was to devise some common scheme for checking what has been called by the Kaiser “the yellow peril.” However slow to learn the Tsar may be, he has discovered by bitter experience the futility and the fatuity of incurring the resentment of the new nationality in the Far East. But that German finance may help Russian states- manship in overcoming one of the obstacles to the conclusion of a lasting peace may well be admitted. Those who wish well to Russia, and who have the strongest faith in the recu- perative power of that great people, cannot conceal from themselves that it will emerge from the disastrous struggle so crippled and exhausted as to render it for a long time an almost inappreciable factor in diplomatic com- binations.
“Daily Graphic.”
The meeting can only be regarded as either a monumental gaucherie or an event of the very highest significance in European politics. And yet it is not easy to sustain either theory.
“GLOBE.”

It would, we believe, be a mistake to attri- bute extreme importance to the meeting of the Kaiser and the Tsar which has just taken place. It is true, that the Emperor William, who is an excellent stage-manager, surrounded it with every circumstance of privacy, and even mys- tery, but we have known less exalted per- sonages do the same thing when they had nothing more important to communicate than a tip for the Derby. Neither Sovereign had his Foreign Minister with him, and, in the circumstances, we are justified in assuming that the Imperial conversation was confined to comparatively unexciting topics.
“Evening Standard.”

If either of the monarchs had been a wiser man, they would have arranged to keep apart. The Tsar will inevitably be represented as a ruler asking alien counsel as to the govern- ment of his realm; the Kaiser will be criti- cised as an officious person anxious to run more of the earth’s surface than it has pleased Providence to set him over. That both sur-

mises are perfectly correct does not make it any the more expedient that they should be made the common talk of every capital. The German Emperor already has so many fingers in so many pies that his subjects begin to view with apprehension the possible intrusion of a carving knife; while, from the point of view of the Tsar’s subjects, the conference almost amounts to an abdication, without the compensations which that step would involve for every thinking subject of Nicho- las II.
“Westminster Gazette.”

We can only speculate as to what the subject-matter of the interview may be. Sweden and Norway is one suggestion, but for our part we feel pretty confident that it is the Far East which has brought the Tsar and the Kaiser together—at the latter’s invitation, so we are told.
“Echo de Paris.”

We ought to be more and more watchful, for Germany pursues her anti-French policy with remarkable tenacity, and it is always the Anglo-French understanding which is aimed at. One must suppose that the under- standing is, indeed, formidable, since Germany is so anxious to break it at any cost.
“Humanite.”

M. Jaures, in the “Humanite” :—“When the Tsar accepted the Emperor William’s in- vitation, and thus resigned himself to wounding and disquiering Great Britain, he entered by the same step into a sort of alliance with Germany, and those of our diplomatists and politicians who in their schemes of foreign policy have not reckoned with the possibility of a Russo-German understanding have been building imaginary edifices on the void.”
“Gaulois.”

The meeting of the two Emperors is an im- portant event... In accepting the interview which was proposed to him the Tsar showed that he is above all preoccupied with the in- ternal situation of his Empire, and desired to discuss matters with a ruler who is able to give him useful advice.
“Aurore.”

M. Clomenceau in the “Aurore” : “What it would be well to bring to the knowledge of Peterhof is that the voyage of the ‘Pole Star’ has given rise to justifiable suspicions here, and that it is not enough to reassure M. Rou- vier in a private interview in order that the country — which to-morrow perhaps will know nothing of M. Rouvier’—should recover its former good disposition towards Russia. We are a democracy.”
“Novoe Vremya.”

If the present interview bears Witness that the heads of European Governments are show- ing themselves fully alive to the situation created by Russia’s painful struggle against the yellow peril which is advancing on Europe, it is all the more matter for congratulation that the initiative should be taken by the representative of the neighbouring people who are bound to us by ties of ancient friendship.
"Lokalanzeiqer” (Berlin).

The “Lokalanzeiger” says Russia now real- ises that she owes her defeat to the machina- tions of England, and since France has chosen to associate herself with England’s policy it is natural that Russia should recollect the old intimate relations existing between her and Germany. The fears entertained in Paris and London, where it is considered the meeting between the two Emperors is a danger to the entente cordiale, are, says the “Lokalanzeiger,” not entirely unfounded.

div.head: NEW OPTIONS, LIMITED.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the members of New Options, Limited, was held on the 20th ulto., at 8, Queen-street-place, London, E.C., for the purpose of considering and, if thought fit, passing resolutions for winding up and reconstructing the company, and appointing Mr. G. H. Wells liquidator.— Mr. Edgar Taylor presided, and, in moving the adoption of the resolutions, said that the directors had considered many propositions, and had not succeeded in finding one offering the required inducements. The country they proposed to operate in was the Sudan, the resources of which had attracted much atten- tion. Under the scheme, it was proposed to join hands with the Mysore Reefs and General Exploration Company, Limited, and to carry on prospecting operations for gold on terri- tory embracing some 1,000 square miles, in which area there had already been located two ancient mining centres of some magnitude. As the scheme did not fall within the powers conferred by the memorandum of association, it was proposed to liquidate, and to form a new company, to be called the New Options Ex- ploration, Limited, with a capital of £5,000 in 50,000 shares of 2s. each, and having memo- randum of association which would enable it to carry on exploration work in any part of the world.—Mr. T Blair seconded the resolu- tions, which were carried unanimously.

div.head: ARMADA RElICS
THE WORK OF RECOVERY AT TOBERMORY.
div.p: Not many years ago Tobermory was the most important town in the Western Islands of Scotland. All the trade of the archipelago was done in the beautifully situated bay of “Mary’s Well.” After an interval of drowsy quiet it is again a scene of bustle and im- portance.

The story of the Almirante Florence and her treacherous blowing up within hail of the foreshore and several cable-lengths from the island of Calve—Tobermory’s natural break- water—was recently given in your columns. That she was a treasure ship the syndicate now searching for her remains is satisfied. Captain Burns, of the Glasgow Salvage Co., who is directing the searching operations, is not a romantic person ; he is a practical man of the world. He would not go on a dream quest. There are, he asserts, positive facts to go upon, and he concludes from them that treasure of considerable value is to be had. He has asked for three months from the syndicate in which to pursue the quest.

Meantime he is going ahead. A photograph of the bottom, over which he is at present working with the salvage steamer Beaver, shows a considerable swell or mound of sand corresponding to the space likely to be occupied by a vessel of the bulk of the Admiral of Florence. Over this sandbank there is a depth of water of about seven fathoms ; in the sur- rounding area there is an almost uniform depth of nine fathoms. The hypothesis is that this formation is caused by an accumulation on, and around, the sunken ship. Captain Burns is satisfied that this theory is correct, because ever since they began working relics in the shape of broken scabbards, boarding hooks, pieces of guns, a pistol, and other curios, in- teresting in themselves, but of little value, have been found among the sand and pebbles.

Among the recent finds, was a well-pre- served blunderbuss, the barrel of which is covered down to the muzzle with wood of very fine quality and as fresh as when the ship went down. The weapon measures 35 inches in length, and the bore is two inches. Other finds are a pistol of small bore, two pieces of lead with 25 per cent. of silver, and a small lamp- stand with three reflectors.
POSITION OF THE VESSEL.

According to the chart of the ground which Captain Burns has had prepared, the Spaniard lies bow down and stern up. In the latter part of the ship he expects to find the gold. He is therefore trying to find it. He estimates that to do so he will require to dig through twenty feet of sand. This, with a digger, would be a simple matter, but in order to avoid damag- ing any valuable objects that may be there he is employing a sand pump and divers. The pump is a centrifugal one, capable of discharg- ing 120 tons per hour. It is worked from the deck of the steamer Beamer, and discharges through a boxed-in sieve on the stern of the vessel.

The diving has been entrusted to Mr. James Gush, of Greenock, whose father Was one of the most famous divers of the West Coast. His work, and that of his assistants, is to keep a clear passage for the action of the pump below water by the removal of all big obstructions, keeping, at the same time, a sharp look-out for “relics.” That this work is being well done is shown from the number of articles already secured. Much of the digging the divers have to do with their hands, much as children dig for shell fish. They would prefer to make a clearance by the use of shot, but the material is much too soft for shot to have any effect.
LEGAL QUESTIONS INVOLVED.

A rather important question is likely to emerge, touching on the right of the syndicate or of the Duke of Argyll, from whom the gold-seekers are said to hold a charter, to carry on the operations. Admitted that the Crown gifted to the Argylls the sunken ship and all it contains, does that right carry power to work, as they are doing, on the foreshore of Tobermory? The pumping is being done directly in front of the pier. The proprietors of the pier hold that the foreshore is theirs. How far their claims in this respect may carry them one cannot say, but they mean, should anything of value be got, to put forward a plea that their share in the property is not a negligible quantity. People are also asking if the Crown had the right to bestow on the Argylls the salvage of the blown-up ship. These matters are only subject for idle speculation at pre- sent, but should the syndicate come, upon bullion of value they may easily become of practical interest. It is also pointed out that Spain was not at war with Scotland at the time the Armada was destroyed. She did not go to that country as an invader, but as a friend, and in search of hospitality, which was accorded her. That there was treachery did not give England the right to rob a Scottish guest—for the gold belonged to the Spaniards. Is it not theirs yet?

All this is, of course, by the way, but it may serve to show that even when Captain Bums and his friends come upon the treasure their troubles may not be over. They will be asked to prove their right to it.

div.head: THE BOSPHORUS DEFENCES.
OUTCRY IN RUSSIA
div.p: A hubbub appears to have been made in Russia because Turkey has added a few guns to the so-called defences of the Bosphorus, the Ottoman entrance-way to the Black Sea But more cry has been raised than is necessary. As a matter of fact, Turkey is not re-arming her forts. When the Potemkin was running amuck and nobody knew where she would draw up, Abdul was warned that her crew might attempt to have a picnic in his river. Where- fore orders were issued for the forts to be strengthened and manned, and for the "Navy” to prepare to give battle to the mutineers should they attempt to invade. Accordingly a couple of rounds per gun were served out to the artillerymen, who slept around their pieces at night ready to spring to action at any mo- ment; searchlights were kept playing from Kavak, where pilotage begins, right down to where the brown river empties itself into, the Black Sea.

At the same time attempts were made to turn the alleged warships into a fleet in being ; but the effort ended in disaster. Steam was got up in the few gunboats and the tor- pedo craft ; but without exception they all broke down and had to be towed back. Some new torpedo-boats recently acquired by the Sultan were ordered out; but they stayed where they were, the builders’ representa- tives refusing to let them be used, as they have not yet been paid for! The Turkish war vessels are not things to be feared. Officials and men are not paid salaries, and they follow the example set by the higher authorities and help themselves. This the naval ratings have done by stealing and selling the brasswork from the engine-rooms and elsewhere, portions of machinery, gun- sights and such things. From which it will be seen that the vessels are not too well fitted to go to sea and stay there, and that the Golden Horn is not well regulated.

As for the forts, they do not strike the expert passing up the river within biscuit-toss of them as being extra formidable. On each flank at the entrance to the Bosphorus there is a masonry work. They are the flowers of the fortifications; but their guns are obsolete. Then on either bank along up the river are other works at intervals—weak and ancient erections, armed with equally ancient guns, almost without exception muzzle-loaders, possibly rifled, possibly not. They have the huge breech and narrow nose that marked the guns of the days when Russia and Turkey were at each other's throats, and it is probable that the majority of them were never fired since, they were installed in their emplacements many years ago, and that their mouths had forgotten the taste of powder when the charges were rammed into them a few weeks ago in readiness for the Russian invaders.

There are only two vessels in his palace- lined waterway that are well kept, if we except the mercantile vessels, the visiting yachts, and the warships of the Powers. They are the Sultan’s two pleasure ships. One of them, an exact replica of the old Victoria and Albert, was presented to Abdul by our late Queen ; the other is a gorgeous steam yacht of about 500 tons, built to the Sultan’s order some years ago. He does not trust them to his own people, who would carry them away bit by bit in lieu of wages ; they are in charge of Englishmen, probably the only employes who get their pay, although the cheques may come in irregularly. The yachts are anchored off the Palace, and are emblems of the Sultan’s splendour; but they are never used and are rotting as they swing at their buoys.

div.head: BRITISH SCHOOL OF ARCHEOLOGY IN EGYPT.
div.p: A meeting of subscribers of the Egyptian Research Account and British School of Ar- chaeology in Egypt was held at University College on Friday week at which the general and executive committees were appointed and the regulations were-adopted. It was announced that the present movement has in a few weeks more than doubled the support of the Research Account, but considerable help is yet needed to enable Professor Flinders Petrie’s excava- tions to be effectively carried on. The coming work will be in a concession of considerable length on the eastern side of the Delta, the district in which traces of the Hyksos kings and the Israelites are most likely to be found. Contributions should be addressed to the secretary of the Research Account at Univer- sity College, London, W.C-, where the exhibition of antiquities from Sinai has just closed.

div.head: GREATER AFRICA.
IMMENSE OPENINGS FOR DEVELOPMENTS.
div.p: [From the “Daily Report.”]

That it is possible to make profits in Africa, even in bad times, and when everybody is grumbling, is shown by the satisfactory report of the New African Company. We hold no brief for this particular undertaking, but its name is mentioned because the details of the report fully bear out our contention of long age, viz: that the Dark Continent has greater poten- tialities of wealth than either Europe, Asia, or America. It is because it is a dark continent as regards its population that it is still so far behind. But things move more rapidly now- a-days than they did a hundred years ago, and the
GIANT STRIDES OF EGYPT

—to take only one part of Africa—in com- mercial and agricultural prosperity are an object-lesson. We now hear of the development of Mozambique, and-the Oceana Company and others are engaged in the cultivation of cotton in the southern portion of that territory, the results of which are considered most promising.
EGYPTIAN COTTON,

of course, is an established product, the area under cultivation in Lower Egypt alone amount- ing to 1,200,000 acres. Then there is Abys- sinia. Business in this country will develop rapidly as the extension of railway com- munication proceeds, and the International
ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY TRUST

and Construction Company has already taken up a number of mineral and other concessions. In West Africa, Cinderella of the gold-mining countries as she has hitherto been—in spite of that sadly misleading province called the Gold Coast—in West Africa satisfactory pro- gress is reported, and there is a, marked im- provement in this prospects of many of the mining companies. The Sudan is being opened up, and Khartoum is
RIVALLING CAIRO

in modern civilisation. All this means trade, and trade means money. The Transvaal and its mines we have with us always. Rhodesia is forging ahead, and, with the markets coming back to normal conditions, prices and dealings will soon resume the importance of former days.

div.head: OUR PARIS LETTER.
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
Paris, July 25.

The subject uppermost in the minds of politicians in this country at the present moment is the unexpected developments of the mission with which the Tsar has en- trusted M. Witte. According to trustworthy reports which have reached Paris, Russia is not only desirous of making her peace with Japan, but is anxious, to contract an alliance with the nation that has humiliated her. She is even willing to pay a war indemnity if this can be brought about, a condition which we have all-along been informed was one to which Russia would never submit. The fact Great Britain—and which she is reported to have recently renewed on closer terms than before—does not appear to be any barrier in the eyes of the Tsar to an alliance be- tween his people and those of the Mikado. On the contrary, if England can be included in the combination that will only render the "entente” all the more powerful, and as France would also be a party to it the result would be an alliance that would ensure the peace of the world for an indefinite period. It will be remarked that Germany does not figure in the new grouping.

Concerning the new Anglo-Japanese treaty, it is stated here that it will comprise more distinct and explicit engagements than before. Japan is to protect and foster Bri- tish interest in the Chinese seas, and Eng- land will withdraw a portion of the powerful fleet which she keeps in the Pacific. In re- turn, England will support the political and economical action of Japan in Manchuria, Corea, and China. As soon as the war is over Japan will send a number of her officers to China to reorganise the Chinese army, and England will support her in the accom- plishment of this scheme against the preten- sions of other Powers, especially Germany.

The cost of living abroad, especially in France, is a question upon which wide vari- ance of opinion exists. In a recent article on the subject, M. A. de Foville, the well-known economist, uses England as a standard of comparison, and says that there is no doubt that the English, on the average, have one- third more to spend than the French, and, all things being equal, more money is earned in England than in France. Further, the cost of living in England is far less than it is in France. The contrary was formerly the case. Butter in France costs 1s. 2 1/2d. to 2s. 6d. per lb., cheese from 1s to 1s. 8d. per lb., and fowls from 2s. to 4s. each. Milk can be had from 3d. per quart, bread 2d. per lb., and meat from 1Od. to 1s. 6d. per lb. Fruit, which is more plentiful and earlier than in England, costs about the same in both countries; bananas and oranges, which Algiers exports by millions, cost a penny and twopence each. Coffee, of better quality than is common in England, costs in France 1s. 8d. to 2s. 6d. per lb. Tea, which is not usually as good as in England, is dearer, and costs from 2s. 6d. to 4s. for ordinary quality ; and sugar 4d. per lb. Coal in Paris is worth £2 8s. to £3 4s. per ton, and in many houses heat is a great rarity. In London two boxes of matches are given for a halfpenny, but in France each box costs a penny (packets of five hundred cost 4d). and they are bad and ill-smelling. Drugs and medicine are almost prohibitively expensive.

M. de Foville presents the balance sheet of four average families. The first family, with an income of £400 per annum, represents a Parisian household : father, mother, two child- ren attending school, and a servant. The second family, with an income of £320, repre- sents a provincial household consisting of a father, mother, two children, and a servant. The third family, with an income of £160, is a Parisian household, consisting of father, mother, a small child, and no servant. And one last is that of a workman's family at Reims, consisting of father, mother, two children, five and ten years of age, the family disposing of a parse of £83 per year. The first family expends £350, and has a balance of £50 for pleasures, doctors, and so forth ; the second family expends £250, and has £70 left, the third, £135, and has a balance of £25 ; and the fourth. £63, with a balance of £20. In the ease of the third family the food consists of coffee, bread and butter for break- fast ; at midday, meat, vegetables, and dessert; at four o’clock the mother and child have chocolate and bread : and at six o’clock there is a dinner of soup, vegetables, and dessert. This is certainly an excellent show- ing for the money at the disposal of the housekeeper.

M de Foville puts his finger on the reason for this successful housekeeping when he says that it lies in the "innate inclination, one might say the passion, for economy. With a few francs the little Parisienne, who may be hungry many days during the year, is able to make herself a hat and frock which many wealthy women might envy. And it is with the table as it is with the toilette. The art of utilising the remnants is an art essentially French, whether it be ribbons or ragouts. The spirit of economy is as common in our country as it is rare in England. Fathers and mothers in France consider themselves the debtors of their children, and even the bachelors think they should leave something behind.”
A former quarter-master of the Farfadet named Hourdel, who has been interviewed at Havre, where he is now employed, throws an interesting light upon one of the causes of the
loss of that submarine. This he attributes largely, if not entirely, to the familiarity with and consequent contempt for danger on the part of both the crews and the officers of sub- marines.

He explains that it was the custom of the Farfadet to leave the manhole open until the last possible moment, so as to avoid the feel- ing of discomfort from the outrush of air, and that the leas; thing—a grain of sand in the mechanism, for instance—might easily prevent the closing of the manhole, and so sink the boat. Of course, the doors of the manhole should be closed, he said, before the plunge, but in practice they very rarely are.

Hourdel was one of the original crew of the Farfadet when she was launched at Rochefort in 1901, and remained with her for nine months. He says that he "much prefers life on a submarine to life on a warship, cruiser, or torpedo-boat. It is quite pleasant under water for twelve hours at a time without re- newing the air, and even at a few feet from the surface you feel neither rocking nor rolling.”

Victor Hugo seems to have lived every where. He began his married life in a street very like the slums ; he finished in the neigh- bourhood of the Etoile. Youthful enthusiasts went in procession on the festival of St. Victor- Hugo’s name day—to a house in the Rue de la Tour-d’Auvergne, where he lived at the moment of his banishment by the Government of the Second Republic. In apartments on the first floor, overlooking the courtyard, Hugo had his residence for a year. The Hugo Pilgrims planted, not a weeping willow such as De Musset asked for, but a small bust in the courtyard. The very concierge who answered the poet’s “Cordon, s’il vous plait!" fifty years ago is still at his post, hale and hearty, and full of Hugo reminiscences, and a neighbour of the great man’s is also still a "locataire.” Paris despite its dissipations has its just pro- portion of nonogenarians.

The death of Arton, of the Panama scandal, has filled the papers with stories of his career. It is now clear enough that he was hard pressed for money, and that this induced him to drink the poisoned cup. Arton was a "noceur” of the most pronounced type. The seamy side of Paris he knew as well as his own (or other people’s) pockets. Shut out from the "monde,” he consoled himself with the "demi- monde.” A great ball that he gave will live in memory. In the midst of it he hurried away to purchase, at twelve o’clock at night in a jeweller’s in the Rue de la Paix, a diamond necklace of great price. It was destined to be- deck a demi-mondaine whose beauty had at- tracted him. Curiously enough, Arton dressed like a funeral mute—the "long-sleever,” frock coat and black trousers, and he never altered even with the temperature as it is now. Per- haps he was in training for really hot weather —elsewhere.

Deroulede’s house at Croissy-les-Roses, a riverine suburb of Paris, has been the Mecca of numerous pilgrimages. The whole neigh- bourhood was disappointed, with the exile, at his non-arrival. There had been a hurried tidy- ing up of the garden, a cutting of belated hay, and a wrestling with great weeds : a luncheon had been prepared, the guests invited, whilst sentimental hearts had poured in flowers and bouquets for M. Deroulede and his sister. An aged dame of the village even bore two em- broidered pincushions as her contribution to the fete. But the flowers have withered and the provisions have grown stale ; it is only the pin-cushions which are unaffected by the exile’s failure to come up to time. It was in this house that Deroulede was arrested in the month of August six years ago. It was here, also, that his uncle, Emile Augier, died. The younger Dumas drove his pony carriage and pair over from Marly to have a final interview with the dramatist. When Deroulede really returns and the calf is killed and eaten in proper season, then the villa will be, like Socrates’ abode, too small to hold his friends.
The “Temps” gives some details of the colli- sion which occurred recently between French and Germans on the Congolese frontier, in which several Senegalese sharpshooters were killed. It says:-

“The frontier between the Congo and the Cameroons being an imaginary line, it is pos- sible that Missoum-Missoum, where the French post was attacked, which is marked as French on French maps, may be marked as German on the German maps. The native sergeant in com- mand of the French troops replied to the Ger- man lieutenant that he was awaiting orders. The German officer seems at least to have shown excessive nervousness, for he fired first on the black sergeant who was advancing alone to meet him. The excuse offered by the lieute- nant that the negro appeared ready to use his weapon does not seem justified, for so little did the Senegalese troops expect an attack that they had their rifles slung across their backs.

"The German detachment killed four of them and seriously wounded others. An agent of the N’Goko Sangha Company, whom the lieutenant afterwards asked to withdraw, re- plied that the proofs produced were not con- vincing, and that he should remain where he was. The German detachment then retired. In consequence of this an official Franco German Mission has been appointed fo delimit the frontier. Whatever its decision, it is certain that the N’Goko-Sangha Company, jn whose employment the sergeant and the men killed were, is entitled to an indemnity.”
Eighty young American women paid a flying visit to Paris front London eight-and-forty

hours ago. They confided to the reporter that they were looking for husbands. In the mean- time they took in as much of Paris as they could, not forgetting the Morgue ; it is to be hoped they were not looking for "him” there. These eighty daughters of Columbia are tra- velling Europe under the aegis of a newspaper and with all their expenses paid. It is remark- able the number of their compatriots ‘doing” Paris at this moment. An average of 2,500 Americans register every month at the ‘Herald” office here. It is to be assumed that does not absorb the whole clan of travelling Americans, but the figures in themselves are sufficiently striking. It is a merciful dispensa- tion of Providence for the Rue de la Paix and and the Avenue de l’Opera that when the Parisian goes out the American comes in. The July tourist from across the Atlantic is the golden bridge from June to October for the jeweller and dressmaker.

The day is still afar off, no doubt when eighty beauteous young women of France, shepherded by the “Figaro” or the “Patrie,” will flatter the male breasts of Cheapside and the Strand ; but a commencement has been made. An anonymous donor has placed a purse, worth £600, at the yearly disposition of the Sorbonne for the use of young French women. They are to travel the countries of Europe and America, visiting those centres where they may be supposed to gain the greatest culture by contact with the educated native. Thus, in the States, they will pat themselves into touch with the women’s universities. It is an interest- ing and novel scheme for France, and points the way to great developments, As an instance of the hold that foreign languages now have upon this nation, one may notice the outcry raised this week over the proposal to render optional living tongues in-the examination for teachers, if the Frenchman is not a born linguist, he is beginning to regret that he isn’t —which is already half-way to being one.

The theatre of St Anne has just opened its doors for the summer season. You will not find such a theatre on the Boulevards, and I doubt if the Automedon of the taximeter ever heard of it. It is certainly a theatre of a somewhat special sort. Its audience are all mad people. St. Anne is an insane asylum on the outskirts of the city. In the summer a little theatre is set up in the great courtyard of the institution and every Sunday evening plays are given for the delectation of the inmates. They take kindly to the entertainment and even applaud in the right place. The theatre plays its part in mental treatment in several of the asylums. At the Asilo de Villejuif, artistes from the Paris theatres beguile the evenings of the patients, and at Charenton the same humane ideas prevail. Salpetriere, the famous hospital for female hysterics, has its costume halls and entertainments, in contrast to the old regime, whereof a print exists to show its horrors. The picture represents the wretched women shut np in cages like wild beasts, their food being thrust in between the bars on the end of forks.

An amusing little incident happened this week at the Etoile station of the Paris "tube,” underneath the Arc de Triomphe. M. Lupine, the Prefect of Police, ran fop a train after the whistle had been blown. The guard, however, slammed the carriage door, and M. Lepine was left upon the platform. The station master, who had seen the incident, telephoned down the line, and when the train got to its jour- ney’s end the guard was reprimanded. "I only did my duty," said the man, "and I deserve no reprimand." "But surely you recognised M. le Prefect’s face?” "Of course I did. And that was another reason for me to prevent him from breaking it,” And M. Lupine thought so too, and sent the man a present for his attention to duty.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent. )
London, July 25.

Second Lieutenant E. T. W. M’Causland, 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, Dublin, has been placed on duty with the draft which is now being prepared by the 1st Battalion for the 2nd Battalion in Egypt. The draft will leave England for Alexandria about the 27th of September.

Captain Herbert Gordon,Leicester Regiment, who recently took up the duties of Assistant Adjutant General of the Egyptian Army, has had close on sixteen years’ military experience. He has the reputation of being a splendid organiser, and no doubt his new appointment will give him opportunities of exercising his well-known capacities. He has done duty with The Khedive’s army since November, 1900.

The recent change in the redistribution of the fleet has resulted in the bringing up of the battle squadron of the Mediterranean Fleet to nine powerful ships, modern in every respect. It is intended to keep the battle squadron at yhat strength for the present. The Channel Fleet will be raised to fifteen battleships, and the Atlantic Fleet to nine battleships, exclu- sive of the cruisers and smaller ships. In con- sequence of these changes the contemplated North Sea Squadron will not be formed—just now. All that Germany has gained by her policy of aggression towards England is the concentration of a naval force within striking distance of her own shores. Any mischief that the German navy was capable of doing has been discounted by the action of that country.
