div.head: MISSIONARY NOBLEMAN
SOCIETY FAVORITE WHO ENTERED THE PRIESTHOOD.
div.p: The United States and Canada have their question of alien immigration, and it is, of course, a far larger one than ours. The visitors from Eastern and South-Eastern Europe are pouring across the Atlantic by the hundred thousand every season. The “Hungarians,” as they are called generically in the States, pro- bably furnish the second largest contingent, coming next after the Italians, and being long ahead of the British, Germans, and Scandi- navians. These people are not all Magyars, though many of them are; others, however, are Bohemians, Gallicians, and Ruthenians, Rou- manians, Serbs, Dalmatians, and Bulgarians. This conglomeration is beginning to colonise whole tracts of the mining and fanning regions of Pennsylvania and Ohio, and is now also spreading itself into Canada.

The sudden shifting of a large population brings evils of its own. These, in the present case, have attracted the attention of a young Hungarian nobleman, who is also a dignitary of the Catholic Church, Monsignor Count Vay de Vaya. The Count, who is not yet thirty, has had an interesting career. He is a mem- ber of a great aristocratic family, a society favorite in Vienna, Pesth, and Agram—where his cousin is the Ban or Governor—and was for some time in the diplomatic service, where a brilliant career lay before him. He threw it up to enter the priesthood, and to become a missionary in the remote places of the earth. He went to Eastern Asia, to China, Korea, and Japan, to ameliorate the conditions of the Christians in those countries. The political troubles which led to the war interfered with his work, and the Count returned and looked into the condition of his countrymen emigrat- ing to the West. He took a number of trips in the great Canard steamers which carry the steerage passengers in huge drafts from Fiume. On one occasion he found himself with 2,400 persons on board one of these vessels, and he delivered a notable sermon to nearly the whole company, who assembled on the upper deck and swarmed over rails, boats, and deck houses to listen to him. The Count Is a wonderful linguist. He speaks most of the dialects of South-Eastern Europe, as well as English, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Latin and a few other languages. His English is as nearly perfect as that of any foreigner can be, and considerably better than that of most natives.
MAGYAR EMIGRANTS.

In the United States and Canada, the apos- tolic protonotary has found abundant scope for his energy. The condition of many of the Hungarian emigrants is deplorable, not so much in the material as in the spiritual and intellectual sense. The Hungarian or Slav immigrant when he leaves his village, driven to the West by the ambition to better himself, or the mere pressure of want, has many good qualities. He is usually simple in his tastes, frugal in his habits, affectionate in his family relations, and naturally religious. Count Vay de Vaya believes that they are in great danger of losing many of these qualities in their new homes. They leave their priests behind, them and the traditions and customs of the old village life. There is a flourishing and powerful Roman Catholic Church in America, but it is long before these new settlers come into touch with it, for its priests speak a language which the immigrants do not understand. They lose their faith, they become Anarchistical, Socialis- tic, and mere materialists ; they become self- indulgent, insubordinate, and riotous, and are looked at askance by their fellow citizens. The Italians often return to their native country when they nave made a little money; the Hungarians remain, and many thoughtful people in America are inclined to regard them as a social and economic danger. Count Vay de Vaya is endeavouring to mitigate these perils by establishing missions among his countrymen in the mining and agricultural regions of the West—to keep them in touch with the Churches, and so to bridge over the transition stage, when they have abandoned their old habits and ideals and have not yet acquired those of Anglo- Saxondom. He has keen passing through London, after one of his tours of inspection, and speaks somewhat hopefully of his enter- prises. He has preached to the factory workers in New York ; and has made a close examina- tion of the immigrant position in Canada, with the encouragement of the Dominion Government. He has also been to Washing- ton, and finds that President Roosevelt is deeply Interested in his attempts to prevent the foreign labourer becoming a mere indus- trial machine, without hope, faith, or. reve- rence. It is work of the more importance since it seems, to quote Count Vay de Vaya, as if we were in face of a veritable Volker- winderwag, a shifting of the population, such as hardly has a parallel in modem times.

This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life.
